Nothingness & Infinity I find Macharia's use of frottage to be very compelling, and I wish to extend it to the other meaning of the word. Of course, Macharia is mainly concerned with the sexual, particularly homosexual, signification, but this use of the word came from the art form of frottage for a reason. They are both exciting for the same reasons. Rubbing the shape of a surface onto a page or a canvas is exciting because the page, contrary to its typical function, now obscures and transforms, and through this process something new, some unexpected texture, is produced. Similarly, rubbing the shape of a body, known or unknown, onto one’s own through the obfuscation of clothing is suggestive and exciting. Following the method of Macharia, I would like to apply this unique form of transmission to a question that Fanon leaves terribly unanswered, to see if, perhaps, what Fanon is missing lies in the grasp of the homosexual Latin American. Within Black Skin, White Masks, Chapter Five, “The Fact of Blackness,” stands out as particularly experimental, with a narrative style that is as beautiful and devastating as it is cogent. Therein is expressed the emotional state of a person of color in colonial modernity: it is a state that ricochets violently. The chapter ends with Fanon crying out, Yesterday, awakening to the world, I saw the sky turn upon itself utterly and wholly. I wanted to rise, but the disemboweled silence fell back upon me, its wings paralyzed. Without responsibility, straddling Nothingness and Infinity, I began to weep (140). Fanon leaves the reader with several open questions. What sort of paradox is this? Is it a dialectic? What makes it so terrible? Most importantly, what is to be done?
Upon Opacity Conclusion: Futurity
